items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)
In the section "The downsides of async/await", it recommends a pattern of using async/await with promises. However, this pattern could lead to an unhandled promise rejection, as explained in Issue #1445. It's not recommended to use this pattern, as explained in the link to stackoverflow provided on Issue #1445.

MDN URL of main page changed
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Asynchronous/Async_await
Issue number (if there is an associated issue)
Fixes #1445
Anything else that could help us review it
I change the title "The downsides of async/await" to "A remark when rewritting code using async/await". I also modified the examples, adding a rejected promise, so that the readers could see immediately in the console that there's an unhandled error. I gave a fix using Promise.all() and add a link to use Promise.allSettled() in case one wants to wait for all promises to settle.
items.title: add a warning and fix the example using Promise.all()

items.content_html:
This PR moves the BCD query from being an argument to {{Compat}} into the page's front matter. This means it's possible to use the BCD query for other page elements, like the specifications table.

See #4537 for the equivalent PR for the JS docs, and #4691 for the next change that this PR unlocks.

This PR doesn't move the query for all pages:

  • some pages don't include BCD at all.

  • a few pages contain more than one BCD table, and these are excluded. For example, https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/gap#browser_compatibility. We might want to try to invent a way around this at some point (e.g. letting a reference page list >1 query in the BCD). That excludes the following:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/justify-content
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_color
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_scrollbars
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/align-content
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/justify-self
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/justify-items
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/align-self
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/break-after
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/row-gap
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/_doublecolon_-webkit-scrollbar
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/gap
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/align-items
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/filter_effects
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/color_value/rgb()
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/color_value/hsl()
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/color_value/hsla()
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/color_value/rgba()
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/break-before
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_counter_styles
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_conditional_rules
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/fit-content()
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/column-gap
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/compositing_and_blending
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_containment
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/pagination
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/card
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/center_an_element
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/list_group_with_badges
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/sticky_footers
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/column_layouts
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/media_objects

  • a few pages that are not reference pages still include compat tables, and we really only want BCD front matter for reference pages. It's a bit tricky to figure out which are reference pages in CSS, but a reasonably accurate heuristic is: if the page title contains a space then it is probably either a guide page or a selectors reference page (like "Attribute selectors"). That excludes the following:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_device_adaptation
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_charsets
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/using_css_custom_properties
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/alternative_style_sheets
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_motion_path
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_namespaces
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/overflow-anchor/guide_to_scroll_anchoring
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_grid_layout/subgrid
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/media_queries/testing_media_queries
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/cssom_view
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/css_animations
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/breadcrumb_navigation
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/split_navigation
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/grid_wrapper
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/web/css/layout_cookbook/contribute_a_recipe/cookbook_template
items.title: Move BCD query into front matter in CSS pages

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

The current return link at the end of the page BookInstance Detail page and challenge points to the top of the Express Tutorial Part 5: Displaying library data page. If readers are at the end of BookInstance Detail page and challenge page, it means that they've finished the tutorial and the backlink they are expecting is Summary section of Express Tutorial Part 5: Displaying library data page.

By updating the link at the end of the BookInstance tutorial page to directly point to the Summary section (the section which is followed just after the BookInstance tutorial) in Express Tutorial Part 5: Displaying library data page, it better suits to a reader's expectations.

MDN URL of main page changed: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Server-side/Express_Nodejs/Displaying_data/BookInstance_detail_page_and_challenge

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Updated return link to point to Summary

items.title: adds border-block and inline interactive examples

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

wss: (WebSocket secure) isn't included in the list of allowed schemes for CSP sources. However this scheme can be used in CSP directives for Web Extensions.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/manifest.json/content_security_policy

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it

This scheme only works in chromium-based browsers and Firefox. So I've opened up another PR to have a browser compatibility note added here: mdn/browser-compat-data#10373
items.title: Add wss to permitted schemes for Web Extensions CSP sources

items.content_html:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SVGStylable

This is marked as deprecated on MDN but not in BCD. I did a search and found SVGStylable.getPresentationAttribute() is deprecated - see https://www.w3.org/Graphics/SVG/WG/track/actions/2696 and the spec https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/types.html#InterfaceSVGStylable - but not whole of SVGStylable.

So what this does is remove the top level deprecation macro and add the inline deprecation for SVGStylable.getPresentationAttribute()

While here I added the bcd compatibility tag/macro, and tidied up the methods section to match MDN standards.

Before I go update BCD, any suggestions on how I can confirm this?
items.title: SVGStylable - deprecated or not?

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

The "four possible output types without initialValue" in the method description are due to incorrect usage of reduce rather than the lack of initialValue argument.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/Reduce

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

#495

I've added examples that illustrate how the reduce method behaves with/without the initialValue argument and for arrays of different lengths. These examples are a direct follow-up to the explanations in the "Description" chapter.
items.title: fix reduce() examples

Similar problems exist around the closing code (and probably every possible and imaginable tag for that matter).

items.content_html:
Users attempting to put requestPostAnimationFrame into production
using polyfills are running into performance problems. Turn this best
practice into a suggestion and add a cautionary note about it.

What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

Users are encountering performance problems on some browsers when using this best practice.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/WebGL_best_practices

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

None

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Downgrade requestPostAnimationFrame rule to a suggestion.

items.content_html:
Currently there are very few entries in the table of contents sidebar;
just "General Topics", "Shaders, Programs, and GLSL", etc., but there
are many individual pieces of advice. h2 entries show up in the TOC,
so promote everything one heading level to make it easier to see all
of the individual pieces of advice at a glance.

What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

Ease of browsing improvement.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/WebGL_best_practices

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

None

Anything else that could help us review it

Somewhat of a matter of opinion, but hoping reviewers will approve.
items.title: Upgrade h2->h1, h3->h2, and so forth.
